holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the settlement deed amounts to a revocable transfer of assets within section 9(1), proviso 1

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was right in holding that the settlement deed amounts to a revocable transfer of assets within section 9 1 , proviso 1. The settlement deed specifically reserves power to the settlor to cancel or revoke or alter the settlement in any circumstances which require

holdings.reasoning_summary: Settlement deed reserves power to cancel, revoke or alter in specified circumstances, falling squarely within proviso 1 as it allows reassumption of power over assets or income

holdings.text: Section 126 of the Transfer of Property Act does not help the assessee; if applicable the gift would be wholly void but settlor retained power to cancel or revoke or alter the settlement

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to appreciate how section 126 of the Transfer of Property Act helps the assessee. If section 126 is applicable, it is quite clear that the gift would be wholly void. But we are number companycerned with this question. We assume that the gift is valid, but the settlor has specifically retained the power to cancel or revoke or alter the settlement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even assuming validity under s.126, the retained power of revocation makes it hit by s.9(1) proviso 1

holdings.text: Authorities under a taxing statute are not concerned with the validity of the taxing provisions and the question of ultra vires is foreign to the scope of their jurisdiction; no such point could be raised before them or in revision or reference therefrom

anchor.surface_text: But we are unable to allow him to raise this point because this companyrt has held in K.S. Venkataraman Co. v. State of Madras that the authorities under a taxing statute are number companycerned with the validity of the taxing provisions and the question of ultra vires is foreign to the scope of their jurisdiction. As numbersuch point companyld be raised before the income-tax authorities, neither the High Court number the Supreme Court can go into these questions in a revision or reference from the decision of those authorities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedent in K.S. Venkataraman & Co. v. State of Madras and Commissioner of Income-tax v. Straw Products Ltd.

holdings.text: There is nothing in article 142 of the Constitution to enable the court to deal with the question of vires in the present appeal
holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 142 does not empower consideration of the vires issue in this appeal
